Hydrodeoxygenation of safflower oil over cobalt-doped metal oxide catalysts for bio-aviation fuel production Alattin Çakan Burcu Kiren Nezihe Ayas ⁎ Eskişehir Technical University, Faculty of Engineering, Department of Chemical Engineering, İki Eylül Campus, Eskişehir 26000, Turkey Eskişehir Technical University Faculty of Engineering Department of Chemical Engineering İki Eylül Campus Eskişehir 26000 Turkey Eskişehir Technical University, Faculty of Engineering, Department of Chemical Engineering, İki Eylül Campus, Eskişehir 26000, Turkey ⁎ Corresponding author. The catalytic hydrodeoxygenation process provides an alternative route for the production of renewable jet fuel, which can directly replace petroleum-derived hydrocarbons. To this end, the catalytic performance of Co-based catalysts supported by different metal oxides, γ-Al2O3, TiO2, ZnO and ZrO2 was tested to evaluate their catalytic activity and product selectivity in hydrodeoxygenation of safflower oil. The results indicated that catalytic performance changed in response to acidity, morphologies and particle size of catalysts. Benefiting from these combined characteristics, Co/ZnO catalyst exhibited a highly catalytic activity, being capable of producing jet fuel-range hydrocarbon selectivity of 65.96% under reaction parameters of 350 °C of reaction temperature, 8 h of reaction time and 75 bar of H2 initial pressure. In addition to superior activity, the coke content of Co/ZnO was much lower compared to other employed catalysts thereby affecting the stability of the catalyst and resulting in less deactivation and coke formation. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Bio-jet Hydrodeoxygenation Safflower oil Catalyst Cobalt Metal oxide supports Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The relevance of the air transport system in the region's closeness and its significant contribution to the international economy has allowed this sector to continue to grow. According to the International Air Transport Association (IATA), the global number of air travelers reached more than 4.3 billion in 2018, while commercial air transport carried 64 million tons of cargo, creating an economic activity worth $6.7 trillion and sustaining 65 million employment. The continued operation of such a huge industry is completely dependent on an uninterrupted fuel supply, thus enhancing the market potential for aviation fuel. Worldwide, the total consumption of aviation fuel for commercial airlines has increased from around 260 million m3/year in 2005, to more than 340 million m3/year in 2018, with an expected increase of 5% by 2050 [1]. For this reason, this demand is on the rise and the large majority are provided by petroleum. Thus, the increasing consumption of fossil fuels and the effects of greenhouse gas emissions on climate change requires the world to focus its efforts on finding aviation fuel alternatives [2]. In this regard, the IATA has set three objectives in 2009, namely to increase the efficiency of the fuel by 1% per year until 2020, achieving carbon neutral growth in 2020 and reducing the net emissions of CO2 by 50% in 2050, compared to the levels of 2005. These targets will be achieved through the "four-pillar" strategy, which consists of investments in technologies, including the advancement of aircraft designs and engine technology, and improving the sustainability of renewable sources of energy, maximizing operational efficiency and optimizing infrastructure efficiency, including the implementation of Air Traffic Control/Management Systems, and the last one is to adopt effective economic measures [3]. The carbon offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA) was another global approach to regulating aviation emissions, taking place under the auspices of the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) in 2016. The scheme consists of three implementation phases the first two phases from 2021 to 2026 of voluntary, followed by mandatory based from 2027 to 2035 [4]. While conversion technologies are being developed by researchers, a sustainable energy system that benefits the economy and environment emerges through bioenergy obtained from biofuels are garnering interest [5]. Therefore, Sustainable aviation fuels (SAF) have been regarded as an excellent solution to help reduce environmental damage due to the carbon footprint of the aviation sector. SAF have been regarded as an excellent solution to help reduce the carbon footprint in the aviation sector. As of May 2019, more than 180.000 commercial flights operated using SAF. Not only does SAF have the potential to reduce aviation greenhouse emissions (GHG), but also delivers far-reaching social, economical, and environmental benefits that include creating a source of income for the local economy, guaranteeing the security of supply as well as having favorable impacts on biodiversity, soil and water quality and land use (forest, wetlands and peatlands) [6]. Conventional petroleum-derived jet fuel contains a large number of hydrocarbons in the range of C9 C16, the most commonly found molecules are n-paraffins (20%), isoparaffins (40%), cycloalkanes (20%), and the rest is aromatic hydrocarbons. The quality of jet fuel is stringently controlled, as its chemical composition plays a paramount role in the combustion performance and emission characteristics of jet fuels. Therefore, the maximum level of aromatics is restricted to 25% by volume while 3000 ppm for sulfur, and 5% by volume for olefins. However, a major difference between bio-derived fuels and conventional jet fuels lies in the absence of aromatic molecules in most renewable aviation fuels which leads to challenges concerning quality, safety and fuel characteristics including lubricity, elastomeric swelling and material compatibility [7]. Thus, the commercial use of such fuels for powering aircraft requires ‘drop-in’ characteristics, meaning that they need to meet rigid jet fuel specifications and have identical behavior to fossil-based fuels during the combustion stage. A particular method to achieve desirable compatibility with the existing fuel systems is by blending fossil fuels with jet biofuels, acting as a drop-in fuel. Presently, several alternative pathways of transformation of sustainable feedstocks into bio-based aviation fuel are deployed, and they are categorized as oil-to-jet, alcohol-to-jet, gas-to-jet and sugar-to-jet [8]. Vegetable oil, composed mainly of triglycerides, could be converted to alkane series ranging from C8 to C16 as fuel for the aviation industry through hydrodeoxygenation (HDO). HDO process consists of eliminating oxygen in the form of oxygenated feedstock such as water and saturation of olefinic bonds under temperatures from 250 to 450 °C and the hydrogen pressures from 10 to 300 bar depending upon features of the reactor and catalyst characteristics [9]. The selection of catalysts for the HDO process is of prime importance in determining product distribution. Because, features of the catalysts including pore structure, pore volume, surface area and acidity of catalysts dictate the catalytic properties of the catalysts [10]. A wide range of experimental runs was performed with different catalysts in the HDO process, including noble metal-based catalysts such as Pt [11], Pd [12], Ru [13], and sulfided catalysts including Pd/γ-Al2O3, CoMo/γ-Al2O3, Ni/SiO2–Al2O3 [14]. However, although noble catalyst is efficient in optimizing jet fuel-range liquid hydrocarbon fuels, being quite expensive presents a significant cost barrier to their application on an industrial scale. Meanwhile, there are also some indications of drawbacks associated with sulfided catalysts, which include resulting in sulfur contamination of the final product, corrosion issues as well as catalyst deactivation due to sulfur leaching [10]. Co-based catalysts, on the other hand, have emerged as promising alternatives for precious metal-based catalysts as they have been proven to promote the deoxygenation of triglycerides [15]. Cobalt-based catalysts are preferentially applied in synthetic biofuel production due to their high selectivity toward long-chain normal paraffin and giving lower content of oxygenate compounds [16]. Srifa et al. [15] assessed the catalytic activity of Co, Ni, Pd and Pt supported on γ-Al2O3 in the deoxygenation of palm oil and showed that the activity for conversion to hydrocarbon fuels follows Co > Pd > Pt > Ni. Naqvi et al. investigated the significance and progress of the catalyst by comparing numerous studies in the literature, including the use of different types of microporous zeolites and metal-loaded zeolites as catalysts in the catalytic deoxygenation process for fuel production from biomass-derived bio-oil [17]. Another important factor affecting catalyst activity is the type of support material due to their beneficial results in terms of enhancing active metal dispersion and support interaction between the catalyst support and active phase as well as improving catalyst surface and varying acidity and basicity. Mesoporous SBA-15, SBA-16 and KIT-6 [18], SAPO-11 [19], ZSM-5 [20], MCM-41 and Hbeta [21] and activated carbon [22] are widely used as support materials. The various metal oxide supports, such as TiO2, Al2O3, ZrO2, CeO2, etc., were also employed for the development of a catalyst for the HDO process due to their moderate acid properties that provide the cleavage of C = O and CO bonds without rapid coke formation [10]. Safflower is an oilseed crop that is well adapted to arid conditions and harsh environments [23]. In addition to being resistant to diseases and pests, it does not pose a serious risk to fallow and crop-planted areas. It is traditionally used for cooking oil and nutritional supplements, however, high-linoleic safflower oil is thought to be deleterious to human health [24]. Oil from safflower contains high levels of polyunsaturated fatty acids, including linoleic (77.9–79.5%) and oleic acid (9.5–11.3%). Taken together, due to the aforementioned facts, it is a potential feedstock for bio-energy applications [25]. Thus, the biorefinery concept based on the use of safflower is promising for biofuel production as it represents an affordable and environmentally benign choice [26]. As far as the scientific literature goes, the HDO of safflower oil aimed at producing bio-jet fuel range hydrocarbons by metal oxides-supported Co catalysts has not been investigated and reported in the literature. Thus, the novel idea of this research is to explore the catalytic activity of a series of Co-based catalysts with different metal oxide supports (γ-Al2O3, TiO2, ZnO and ZrO2) in HDO of safflower oil. Additionally, extensive characterization of synthesized catalysts was carried out to scrutinize the role of support materials and Co comparatively in the HDO process. 2 Material and methods 2.1 Materials Safflower oil, which was provided by the Geçit Kuşağı Agricultural Research Center (Eskişehir, Turkey), was used as a source of renewable materials for this study. The composition of the fatty acids in the safflower oil, determined by gas chromatography, is shown in Table 1 and was included in the earlier work of the author [27]. The safflower oil comprises the highest percentage of long-chain mono and polyunsaturated fatty acids: oleic (37.85%), linoleic (44.62%) and followed by palmitic (7.41%), linolenic (5.60%), stearic (2.83%) and arachidic (1.69%) as trace amounts of other fatty acids. Generally, the degree of unsaturated oil content directly influences the bio-hydrocarbon production, and oil containing unsaturated fatty acids may undergo further catalytic reactions, including cracking and isomerization, since the double- and triple-bond sites of the fed oil interact easily with the active catalyst sites [28]. Hydrogen (H2, 99.9%) and nitrogen (N2, 99.9%) were supplied by Oksan company. The chemicals used in the experiment include Co(NO3)2·6H2O (Merck, 99%), γ-Al2O3 (Sigma-Aldrich), TiO2 (Sigma-Aldrich, ≥ 99.5%), ZnO (Sigma-Aldrich), ZrO2 (Merck) and they were used as received. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts A series of supported catalysts were synthesized by a conventional wet impregnation method using cobalt (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2•6H2O) with a controlled metal loading of 10 wt%. In a typical procedure, a required amount of Co(NO3)2•6H2O was dissolved in a certain amount of distilled water. This solution was then immediately poured over the predetermined amount of catalyst support (γ-Al2O3, TiO2, ZnO and ZrO2) evenly and the resultant solution was magnetically stirred at a rate of 400 rpm and heated to 80 °C for 6 h to ensure that the entire pore volume of the catalyst was impregnated. Following this, the impregnated catalyst was placed in a 105 °C oven for one day [29]. As a final preparation step, the catalyst was calcined at 500 °C for 4 h. The scheme of catalyst preparation is presented in Fig. 1 . 2.3 Catalyst characterization 2.3.1 X-Ray fluorescence (XRF) spectroscopy Rigaku ZSX100e XRF (Tokyo, Japan) spectrometry was used for the identification of the bulk composition of Co-impregnated catalysts. The working distance was 15 mm and the acceleration voltage was 20 kV. The working voltage and the working currents were 50 kV and 50 mA, respectively. Loss on Ignition (LOI) was determined by heating the prepared catalysts at 1050 °C for 2 h to estimate total volatile matter components. 2.3.2 X-Ray diffraction (XRD) XRD analysis of catalysts was performed on a Rigaku Rint 2200 (Rigaku Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) diffractometer equipped with a 1.8 kW CuKα tube (λ = 1.54056 Å) and operating at 40 kV and 40 mA. The X-ray diffractogram of all the catalysts from 10° to 80° at a scanning step of 0.02°/s was recorded. The diffraction peaks were identified using powder diffraction files by the Crystallography Open Database (COD). The X-ray tube voltage and current were set at 40 kV and 40 mA, respectively. 2.3.3 Particle-size distribution The mean particle size and the volume particle size distribution of supports and corresponding catalysts were determined on a Malvern Instruments Mastersizer 2000® (Malvern Instruments, Worcestershire, UK) laser diffractometer with a suitable Standard Operating Procedure in aqueous suspensions. Diameters or volumes of supports and corresponding catalysts aggregate in distilled water suspensions were supplied by measuring the intensity of a scattered He–Ne laser (λ = 632.8 nm) beam passing through dispersed and stirred corresponding aqueous suspensions. The diameters at 10%, 50%, and 90% cumulative percentage (d10, d50, and d90) represent cumulative undersized volumes, respectively. 2.3.4 Thermal gravity/derivative thermal gravity (TG/DTG) analysis TG/DTG of all catalysts was done by Perkin Elmer STA 6000 at the heating rate of 10 °C min−1 from 30 to 800 °C under a highly purified N2 atmosphere (50 mL/min). The sample weight used for TG/DTG analysis was approximately 10 mg. 2.3.5 Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) pore volume and surface area analysis Adsorption-desorption isotherms of nitrogen were obtained at 77 K using a Micromeritic ASAP 2020 instrument (Micromeritics Instrument Corp, USA). Additionally, from the obtained adsorption-desorption isotherms, the specific surface area was determined using the BET method. The pore volume and pore size distribution were derived from the desorption branch of sorption curves, using the Barrett Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. The isotherms were measured over the relative pressure range from 0.01 to 0.991 and back. Before the analysis, the fresh catalysts were pre-treated under vacuum at 300 °C for 3 h. 2.3.6 Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) All catalysts were gold-palladium coated using a Denton Vacuum Desk II gold-cathode sputter to reduce sample charging and characterized through a ZEISS-SUPRA 50 VP, Germany, field emission gun–scanning electron microscope at 20 kV. The microscope is operated under a high vacuum, using immersion mode with a through-the-lens detector, at a working distance of 10 mm. 2.3.7 Catalysts acidity measurement Ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) analyses of the catalysts were performed on the Autochem II-2920, Micromeritics, unit equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Before the measurement, the samples were heated at 500 °C for 1 h in He gas flow. After that, these samples were cooled down to the room temperature and exposed to a flow of 15% NH3/He mixed gas. Then, the system was flushed by He at 100 °C to eliminate physically adsorbed NH3 molecules from the sample surface. The samples were heated at the rate of 10 °C/min from the room temperature to 500 °C in He flow for NH3 desorption. The TCD detected the amount of NH3 desorbed. Pyridine adsorbed diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) with a spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific-Nicolet iS10) was used to assess the relative number of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites on the catalyst surface. Before the measurement, all catalysts were evacuated at 110 °C for evaporation of adsorbed water on their surface, and then pyridine adsorbed catalysts were kept at 40 °C for 1 h. Thereafter, all catalysts were treated with pyridine, and subsequently, DRIFTS analysis of both clean and pyridine-adsorbed samples was performed at the room temperature. Later, to analyze the acidic nature of the sample, the spectra of the clean sample were subtracted from the spectra of the pyridine-adsorbed sample. The formula in the reported reference [30] using the integrated molar extinction coefficients (IMEC) and integrated peak area values was used to determine the Brønsted and Lewis acid concentrations of the pyridine-adsorbed samples. 2.3.8 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) The surface functionalization and chemical composition of synthesized catalysts were performed on Specs-Flex. All measurements were performed using an AlKα excitation source at 225 W operating at 15 kV and all binding energies were referenced to the C 1s at 284.6 eV. The fits of the data were accomplished using a Gaussian-Lorentzian peak shape after a Shirley background correction. 2.4 Experimental set-up The activity and selectivity of each catalyst were determined using a high-temperature, high-pressure Parr autoclave reactor (Parr Instruments Co., Inc. USA, model 4575). The reactor has a 500 mL capacity and the maximum operating conditions of temperature and pressure were 500 °C and 5000 psi, respectively. All reactions were conducted under constant stirring of 500 rpm. The experimental apparatus is composed of three main parts, including a stainless-steel batch reactor, gas/liquid separator and controller. The vessel head is equipped with a gage adapter and a vent needle valve, gasses are admitted into the system through a needle valve. An aluminum block heater is employed, and the temperature is controlled by the Series 4843 Controller. Additionally, the reactor chamber is hermetically closed; hence the pressure is directly proportional to the temperature. Fig. 2 shows the configuration of a typical batch reactor. Once the desired operation is reached, the reactor is cooled down to the room temperature. 2.5 Experimental procedure The reactor was loaded with 100 mL of safflower oil, with 1% of the catalyst, in absence of a solvent. Prior to each run, the reactor and all connecting lines were purged with N2 and then H2 was pressurized to the intended value at ambient temperature. First, the catalytic activity of Co/γ-Al2O3 was evaluated under different reaction parameters; reaction time (4, 6, 8 h), reaction temperature (300, 350, 400 °C) and initial H2 pressure (25, 50, 75 bar). Thereafter, after determining suitable operating conditions for Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the catalytic performance of catalysts under the same operating conditions with different support materials (TiO2, ZnO and ZrO2) was tested for the catalytic activity comparison. After completion of the reaction, the reactor was cooled to the room temperature, the resultant products and catalyst were separated via centrifugation. The weight of the liquid products was measured on a balance and the liquid products were analyzed through gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS). 2.6 Product analysis To better explore the catalytic activity of synthesized catalysts on organic liquid products, the GC–MS (Agilent Technologies, model 7820A) analysis was applied to examine the composition of products. Compound identification was achieved by GC–MS equipped with a capillary column HP-5 (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm film thickness). The injection port temperature was set to 320 °C. The GC program for the column was as follows: initial temperature of 30 to 80 °C at a rate of 2 °C/min. Then, raised to 300 °C, ramp at 10 °C per minute and hold for 20 min. Quantitative analysis was performed using the area normalization method based on the peak area percentages of the identified components. The helium (99.999%) carrier gas flow through the column was 1.0 mL/min, and the MS was operated over the range from 0 to 300 m/z. The obtained chromatographic peaks were identified using the Wiley library. This protocol was obtained from the reference [21]. The catalytic activities of synthesized catalysts were calculated as shown in the following equations [31,32]: (1) L i q u i d m a s s y i e l d ( % ) = m a s s o f l i q u i d p r o d u c t o b t a i n e d m a s s o f f e e d × 100 (2) S x ( % ) = C x ∑ n x × 100 Where Sx defines gasoline/jet/diesel selectivity, Cx represents the relative percentage of the peak area of gasoline (C5 C7)/jet (C8 C16)/diesel (C17 C21) hydrocarbon fraction, and nx describes the total peak area of hydrocarbons. The Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectra of all resultant products were obtained using a Thermo Fisher Scientific-Nicolet iS10 FTIR spectrometer (Waltham, MA, USA) using the ATR technique. The spectra were recorded in the range of 4000–450 cm−1 at a resolution of 4 cm−1 with 16 scans. Spectra were recorded and analyzed using OMNIC 9 software package. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 XRF analysis The bulk chemical composition of synthesized catalysts was determined through XRF, and the results are reported in Table 2 . According to Table 2, metal oxides (support materials) are the significant ingredient in the structure of each catalyst while the loading amount of Co2O3 are almost similar (ranging from 14.40 to 14.70%). Therefore, Co impregnated on various metal oxides are in close agreement with theoretical formulations, confirming that all sample was successfully loaded onto the metal oxide supports and no cobalt species were lost during the impregnation process. Apart from these components, each catalyst contains a trace amount of impurities depending on the support material and precursor. Additionally, Co/ZrO2 showed a low organic content as proved by the LOI value (0.83%), which was determined by burning the sample in a muffle furnace at 1050 °C for 2 h. 3.1.2 Thermal analysis TG/DTG analysis was performed to investigate the thermal decomposition behavior of the synthesized catalysts. The thermal stability measurements were recorded in the N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min, and corresponding TG/DTG analysis results are shown in Fig. 3 . Based on the thermal disintegration curve, the thermal behavior of Co/ZnO, Co/γ-Al2O3, and Co/ZrO2 are quite similar. The TG/DTG profiles of these catalysts displayed a considerable mass loss of up to 22 wt% in the temperature range of 30 to 280 °C. In contrast, Co/TiO2 exhibited different changes in its weight, and the thermogram of Co/TiO2 revealed an initial weight loss between 30 and 250 °C with a weight loss of about 14 wt%, and afterward, a small decomposition step occurred at 665 °C. Thus, it is clear that Co/TiO2 catalyst is thermally more stable than the other catalysts. During these weight loss events, surface-adsorbed water and other adsorbed organic functional groups presumably were driven off from the catalysts [33]. 3.1.3 X-Ray diffraction (XRD) analysis The crystal structures of bare metal oxides and the Co-containing metal were investigated by XRD to make phase identification of materials and corresponding results were shown in Fig. 4 (a-b). The results in Fig. 4(a) showed that visible diffraction peaks at about 2θ = 37.76°, 45.72° and 67.06° were assigned to the characteristic diffraction peak of γ-Al2O3 (COD Card Number 9007635) [34]. The XRD analysis of TiO2 revealed that the sample exhibited both anatase and rutile crystalline phases of TiO2. The 2-theta peaks at around 25.42°, 36.20°, 48.14°, 54.10°, 62.86°, 69.08° and 75.16° correspond to the anatase phase of TiO2 (COD Card Number 9015929). On the other hand, the peaks observed at 2θ = 27.54°, 36.20 °, 41.40° and 56.74° are identified to be the rutile phase of TiO2 (COD Card Number 9015662) [35]. The XRD spectra of ZnO at 2θ = 31.83°, 34.52°, 36.28°, 47.58°, 56,64°, 62.89°, 67.43°, 72.58° and 77.01° were well matched with the hexagonal zincite phase of bulk ZnO (COD Card Number 1011259) [36]. For the bare ZrO2, The diffraction peaks at 2θ = 17,38°, 24.00, 28.06°, 31.38°, 34.04°, 35.10°, 35.26°, 40.82°, 48.40°, 50.04°, 55.48°, 59.98°, 62.68° and 65.74° were ascribed to the monoclinic phase baddeleyite crystals (COD Card Number 1010912) [37]. From the XRD results of Co/γ-Al2O3, the diffraction peaks of the catalyst can be well indexed to the standard spinel phase (Co3O4, CoAl2O4 or Co2AlO4) and the additional phase corresponds to γ-Al2O3 and CoO. Co3O4, CoAl2O4 or Co2AlO4 crystallize in the same space group with similar cell parameters, thereby showing similar XRD patterns [38]. Besides it, the diffraction peak at about 2θ = 18.93° is related to CoO (COD Card Number 9008618) [39]. The XRD profile of Co/TiO2 exhibits peaks corresponding to the [221], [310], [112], [200] diffraction peaks appearing at 2θ = 38.60°, 59.46°, 69.02°, 70.36° (COD Card Number 5910080) of cobalt titanate [40]. XRD profile of the Co/ZnO catalyst is dominated by the high-intensity peak of hexagonal ZnO with zincite structure [41]. The corresponding diffraction rings attribute to the lattice planes [100], [002], [101], [102], [110], [103], [200], [112], [201], [004] and [202] which are in good agreement with those obtained from other publication [42]. Meanwhile, the diffraction peaks located at 2θ= 18.92°, 31.22°, 36.36°, 44.54°, 59.02°, 64.86° and 77.02° in the XRD pattern of the Co/ZnO sample suggest the presence of Co3O4 (COD Card Number 9005895). The characteristic diffraction peak of the crystalline Co3O4 particles at 2θ = 18.92°, 36.36° and 65.56° were shown by the XRD diffractogram of Co/ZrO2 [43,44]. 3.1.4 Particle-size distribution A laser beam scattering technique was carried out to get insight into the hydrodynamic particle size of both supports and corresponding catalysts. The result for particle size distribution is demonstrated in Fig. 5 , and the variations of d10, d50 and d90 are summarized in Table 3 . This technique allows real-time determination of particle size in aqueous suspensions. According to Fig. 5(a) and (b), the particle size distribution varied among different types of metal oxide supports but also within their corresponding catalysts. Particularly, the particle size distribution of Co/TiO2 appeared to be broader, more importantly, shifted towards larger sizes, than that of its parent material i.e. TiO2, which is consistent with the SEM images. It was apparent that Co/ZnO and Co/ZrO2 displayed a very similar particle size distribution, whereas γ-Al2O3 kept the particle size distribution in a narrow range after being impregnated with Co, constituting a narrow range of particle sizes rather than a large size variation. A comparison of the results for a series of supports and corresponding Co-based metal oxide catalysts indicated that different supported Co catalysts showed a vast difference in characteristic particle diameter. When looking at each catalyst, it was found that Co/ZnO possessed the smallest median diameter (d50, which is commonly used to represent the average particle size of powders) of 4.769 µm whereas Co/TiO2 characterized by the highest average particle diameter equal to 112.629 μm. Likewise, the collected data also showed that Co/ZnO displayed the smallest other characteristic diameters of d10 and d90, which were 1.426 and 25.409 μm, respectively. 3.1.5 Microscopic analysis of catalysts The surface morphology of the metal oxide supports and their corresponding catalysts were studied by SEM, and Fig. 6 shows the SEM investigations of both supports and catalysts. Additionally, energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping, presented in Fig. 6, was to further confirm the Co distributions. SEM images of as received γ-Al2O3 show a well-defined multi-layered crystal structure with smooth surfaces [45]. However, the morphology of the support material significantly changed when doped with Co, and the surface morphology transformed to feature a collection of Co scatters particles, although also, some irregular-shaped blocks are visible. From the SEM micrograph of bare TiO2, shown in Fig. 6, it can be seen that TiO2 revealed a spherical morphology with a highly clumped distribution [46]. The SEM micrograph of synthesized Co/TiO2 revealed that Co crystallites formed an aggregate layer on the TiO2, resulting in irregularly-shaped agglomerates of small rice-like crystallites [47,48]. The SEM images of the undoped ZnO sample demonstrated a homogeneous structure and were equally distributed across the sample [49]. However, the addition of Co was found to occur in particles that have irregular shapes and broad size distribution. From the surface morphology of undoped ZrO2 observation, larger grains are distributed randomly and it indicates the formation of microvoids in grain and some larger voids in grain boundary of unmodified ZrO2. Apparently, with the addition of Co, Co particles were dispersed regularly on the surface of ZrO2 with cluster-like micro-crystals. To confirm the incorporation of both Co within the metal oxide supports, elemental mapping through SEM coupled with the EDS was taken and presented in Fig. 6. The light dots represent Co while support surface is depicted in dark color in the EDS mapping. The mapping on the catalysts showed uniform distribution of Co throughout all supports. 3.1.6 Physicochemical analysis and textural properties of the catalysts The results of the gas adsorption experiments for all support materials and corresponding catalysts are illustrated in Table 4 . BJH and BET methods were used to determine pore size volume and the specific surface area, successively. According to Table 4, ZrO2 exhibited the lowest surface area (1.307 m2/g), whereas γ-Al2O3 has the highest surface area (135.988 m2/g). It is evident from the table that the textural properties of catalysts were observed to change markedly by changing the nature of support materials. Additionally, the incorporation of Co caused a decrease in the surface area of γ-Al2O3 and TiO2, which was presumably due to the occupation of Co particles on the surface, resulting in blocking the available pores in supports. Besides, consistent with the results of SEM images of Co/γ-Al2O3 and Co/TiO2 catalysts, clusters with relatively large size in some places might lead to a reduction in the surface area of catalysts. The external surface area of catalysts also followed the same manner with the addition of Co. On the other hand, the opposite trend was clearly seen for both ZrO2 and ZnO, as their specific surface area emerged to rise upon impregnation with Co. A similar observation was made in the literature regarding doping of zinc oxide nanoparticles with calcium, showing modifying zinc oxide with calcium resulted in irregular shape and size on the external surface of catalysts, which, in turn, contributed to the increased surface area [49]. The enhancement in the surface area of catalysts has facilitated the formation of well-dispersed Co species into small particles on the surface of the catalyst [50]. In general, after impregnation with Co, the average pore radius increased as compared to bare supports and was in the sequence of Co/TiO2 > Co/ZrO2 > Co/ZnO > Co/γ-Al2O3. Additionally, the average pore diameter of all supports and their corresponding catalysts are less than 50 nm, which is consistent with mesoporous materials. Unlike Co/γ-Al2O3, Co addition was also observed to influence on pore volume of catalysts, and the pore volume of catalysts could be ranked as follows: Co/γ-Al2O3 > Co/TiO2 > Co/ZnO > Co/ZrO2. These results indicate a modification of pore texture as a result of the impregnation and calcination method. Fig. 7 demonstrates the typical N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of supports and prepared metal oxide catalysts. Data curves of N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of metal oxide supports demonstrated that the textural features of supports differed significantly from one to another. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of γ-Al2O3 shows that all the alumina particles showed the classical shape of a Type IV isotherm curve with an H1-type hysteresis loop in the P/P0 range of ∼0.4–0.95, which are typical for mesoporous materials according to the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) classification. This type of loop is associated with typical characteristics of mesoporous materials containing agglomerates of plate-like particles with slit shape pore materials [38]. TiO2, on the contrary, exhibited slightly different isotherms, and it was identified as a type IV isotherm with an H3 type hysteresis loop, representing slit-like mesopore entrance nature [51]. It is also salient to note that at high relative pressure, this hysteresis did not experience a plateau, which demonstrated the existence of macropores and cumulate interspaces in the TiO2 [52]. The SEM images in Fig. 6 also confirmed certain interspace regions within the structure of TiO2. Additionally, the isotherm of ZnO corresponds to a type III isotherm with a narrow hysteresis loop at high relative pressure, indicating that the sample was of mesoporous feature [53]. The isotherm of ZrO2 exhibited type IV isotherm with H2 hysteresis loop, as aspected for low porous or non-porous materials [54]. The nonporous morphology of the ZrO2 was also confirmed by SEM analysis and BET surface area measurement. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of Co/γ-Al2O3 and Co/ZrO2 were found to be similar to those of the pristine metal oxides shown in Fig. 7, providing that Co incorporation via impregnation procedure has a relatively subtle effect on their porosity. By contrast, the adsorption/desorption isotherm of the Co/TiO2 possessed a type IV curve with a wider hysteresis loop, as compared to pristine TiO2, at relatively high relative pressure, suggesting a mesoporous structure [55]. It is worth noting that the hysteresis loop of Co/ZnO become somewhat more spread out at high relative pressure of ∼0.85, which was likely to be the result of augmented surface area upon the addition of Co [56]. 3.1.7 Catalysts acidity measurement and acidic properties The NH3-TPD profiles of different metal oxide-supported Co catalysts to evaluate their surface acidic properties are given in Fig. 8 . Based on the peak temperature of desorption, the acid strength of the surface of the solid could be categorized into a strong (> 400 °C), a medium-strong (200–400 °C) and a weak (below 200 °C) [57]. It is noticed that the total acidity of catalysts is quite unlike, signifying that the acidity of the catalyst was closely related to the nature of the supports used. Therefore, the intensity of the desorption peak and its position, as shown in Fig. 8, mainly depended on the type of support. The results of the characterization of NH3-TPD showed that all prepared metal oxide-supported catalysts, except for the Co/γ-Al2O3, possessed weak, moderate and strong acid sites. Specifically, the Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited a small desorption peak at approximately 183 °C and the main reduction peak at approximately 300 °C was assigned to weak and moderate strength acid sites, respectively. This finding was also supported by a similar observation reported by Cai et al. [58]. The deconvoluted peaks of the Co/TiO2 catalyst, on the other hand, could be classified into three kinds of acid strength corresponding to NH3-eluted temperature, which confirmed the existence of weak, medium and strong acid sites. In the case of Co/ZnO, there were also three peaks: the sharp desorption peak with a maximum desorption temperature at 227 °C, and the slightly broader desorption peak with a maximum desorption temperature at 380 °C, confining a considerable number of acidic sites of weak strength and acidic sites of medium strength, respectively [59]. Apart from them, the first peak had a maximum of around 100 °C corresponding to weak acid sites on the catalyst surface. A similar kind of desorption behavior was observed from the NH3-TPD profile of Co/ZrO2 but with lower intensity and strength of the acid sites. According to pertinent literature, the strength and the number of acidic sites were reflected by the desorption temperature and area of the peak [60]. In this respect, based on the area of desorption peak, the total acid content of catalysts showed a decreasing trend as follows: Co/γ-Al2O3 > Co/TiO2 > Co/ZnO > Co/ZrO2. Furthermore, in the interest of investigating the effects of the acidity species on the performance of the catalysts, a series of DRIFTS experiments were carried out and the results of the resultant spectra of catalysts were determined, as illustrated in Fig. 9 . For Co/γ-Al2O3, the intensive band at 1444 cm−1 and the band at 1591 cm−1 of low intensity signified characteristics of pyridinium ions (C5H6N+) coordinately bonded to Lewis acid sites. Besides, the most characteristic band of adsorption of pyridine on the Brønsted site, which occurred frequently near 1535 cm−1, was also found in spectral data of the catalyst based on γ-Al2O3 [61]. The spectra of pyridine adsorbed on Co/TiO2 exhibited the bands of 1604, 1573 and 1444 cm−1 which were attributed to Lewis acid sites; the bands of 1641 cm−1 and 1543 cm−1 indicated the existence of a coordinately bonded pyridine at Brønsted acid sites, while a band of 1490 cm−1 was assigned to Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [62]. Being complying with NH3-TPD results, it is noted that Co/ZnO had relatively low intensity and a weaker Lewis and Brønsted acid character. For more detail, the resulting adsorbance bands showed that pyridine molecules were retained with bands of coordinative adsorption on Lewis acid sites in the ranges of 1438–1455 cm−1 and 1576–1622 cm−1, whereas Brønsted acid sites were typically observed at 1636–1653 cm−1. Additionally, Co/ZrO2 exhibited mainly weak Lewis acid sites at 1585 and 1442 cm−1 [63]. The Brønsted and Lewis acid concentrations (µmol/g) were calculated based on the formula given in the literature [30], using the integrated peak area, IMEC, weight of disk analyzed, and disk diameter data. The acid concentration values (µmol/gcat) calculated using the integral peak area values obtained from the DRIFTS spectra are listed in Table 5 . According to Table 5, the obvious variation between the Brønsted and Lewis acid concentrations of the catalysts with different supports appears to be due to the nature of the support materials. Observing the concentration of the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, it is seen that the concentration of Lewis acid sites are greater, and the results are in agreement with the DRIFT spectrum. In addition, consistent with the acidity comparisons obtained from the NH3-TPD analysis, Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst had the highest acid content, whereas Co/ZnO and Co/ZrO2 catalysts displayed a similar tendency; however, Co/ZrO2 catalyst has the lowest acid value. 3.1.8 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra To better understand the interaction of active components in the systems and to obtain more detailed information regarding the compositions and the bonding conditions of the synthesized catalysts, the XPS measurements were applied. Fig. 10 (a) presents the survey scan XPS spectra of Co/γ-Al2O3, Co/TiO2, Co/ZnO and Co/ZrO2. Fig. 10(b) depicts the high-resolution Co 2p region, and Fig. 10(c) shows XPS spectra of the O 1s peak band of all samples. As presented in Fig. 10(a), the existence of Co on the surfaces of metal oxides has also been confirmed by the XPS. Besides it, all the catalyst samples exhibited prominently their distinguished peaks on the basis of their metal-oxide natures, showing Al 2p, Ti 2p, Zn 2p and Zr 3p spectral for Co/γ-Al2O3, Co/TiO2, Co/ZnO and Co/ZrO2, respectively. According to the Co 2p spectrum of Co/γ-Al2O3 shown in Fig. 10(b), the principal peaks of Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 at their high binding energy sides demonstrated shoulder which might be due to the shake-up transition peaks, corresponding to Co2+in a high spin state. The Co3O4 is not very strong (the ratio Co3+/ Co2+ is 2:1 for Co3O4), since the Co3+ ions with a low spin did not present a shake-up structure [64,65]. Therefore, the main peak of Co 2p3/2 could be assigned to the presence of CoAl2O4. As regards the cobalt distribution in the support of TiO2, XPS data indicated that the peaks corresponding to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 were located at binding energies of 781 and 795.8 eV, respectively. Co 2p3/2 indicated that the surface cobalt largely presented the formation of CoTiO3, which was 5.9 eV higher in binding energy than that of the Co 2p3/2 [66]. Besides, Co 2p1/2 with the satellite peak around 802 eV confirmed the presence of CoO on the surface of mesoporous Co/TiO2 [67]. On the other hand, regarding Co/ZnO and Co/ZrO2, Co 2p3/2 peaks become sharper than those previously mentioned. XPS spectra of Co/ZnO exhibited metallic Co peaks at 778.5 eV and 793.7 eV, belonging to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, respectively. In addition, the presence of some weak satellite structures represented the contribution of cobalt oxide phases (typically Co3O4 or CoO) [68]. The Co 2p region of Co/ZrO2 with a prominent peak centered at 779.6 eV (Co 2p3/2) and 795.1 eV (Co 2p1/2), which is characteristic of a Co3O4 phase [44]. The above results correspond to the results of the XRD, and they suggest that the development of different cobalt phases is largely dependent on the chemical properties and physical characteristics of the support material. Fig. 10(c) presented the peak splitting results of the elemental oxygen spectrum and the XPS spectrum of O 1s for Co/γ-Al2O3 was a combination of two deconvoluted peaks that came from lattice oxygen at 530.4 eV and surface adsorbed oxygen at 531.6 eV [69]. Regarding the Co/TiO2, the O 1s spectrum was fitted by two peaks, at 528.9 and 531.1 eV. The former was assigned to surface lattice oxygen species from support and metal oxide phases and the latter binding energy was associated with surface hydroxyl groups [70]. The O 1s spectra of Co/ZnO can be deconvoluted with three peaks, the peak fitted with the component at 529.9 eV could be attributed to the lattice oxygen in the metal oxides, the higher binding energy peak at 530.0 eV could be associated with oxygen ions in the oxygen-deficient regions within the ZnO matrix and was related to oxygen vacancies [71]. The O 1s spectra of Co/ZrO2 can be characterized as a result of overlapping two components in the vicinity of 529.7 and 531.3 eV, the first of which is due to the surface lattice oxygen and the second peak at a higher level of binding energy is related to surface oxygen from hydroxyl and/or water molecules adsorbed on the material [72]. 3.2 The impact of reaction conditions One of the particular ways to process fatty acids for biofuel production is deoxygenation which is based on two individual mechanisms, namely decarboxylation/decarbonylation and HDO reactions. The former mechanism is related to the removal of oxygen atoms in the fatty acid in the form of CO and CO2, respectively, to produce alkanes with one carbon lesser than the original fatty acid. The latter mechanism facilitates the scission of the CO bond and thereby saturating double bonds of triglycerides by the possibility of removing oxygen (in the form of water). Therefore, the extent to which these processes take place relies on the nature of the catalyst and reaction conditions [73]. In this means, in the current study, the catalytic HDO of safflower oil was studied at different key reaction conditions, namely reaction temperature (300–400 °C), reaction time (4–8 h), hydrogen pressure (25–75 bar) in presence of Co/γ-Al2O3. Upon establishing the best catalytic condition for safflower oil, different types of metal oxide-supported Co catalysts (Co/TiO2, Co/ZnO and Co/ZrO2) were subjected to the same reaction under the determined conditions. It was observed that the total system pressure increased approximately two times above the initial hydrogen pressure during the reaction. 3.2.1 Effect of the reaction temperature One major factor in the catalytic HDO process strongly affecting the reaction performance is the reaction temperature. In the considered experimental conditions, reaction time and hydrogen pressure were kept constant at 4 h and 25 bar, respectively, and the experiments were carried out at different temperatures of 300 °C, 350 °C and 400 °C to assess the influence of temperature on the catalytic HDO process of safflower oil, and the corresponding results are given in Fig. 11 . According to the experimental results of Fig. 11(a), the liquid mass yield of safflower oil sharply decreased from 96.11% to 71.26%, as the temperature was raised incrementally from 300 °C to 400 °C. This indicates that high temperatures facilitated the coke formation on the surface of Co/γ-Al2O3 which caused deactivation during catalytic HDO reactions (as illustrated schematically in Fig. 17) thus reducing liquid product yield [74]. As shown in Fig. 11(a), the initial temperature of 300 °C was not substantial enough for the cracking of safflower oil triglycerides, resulting in a high amount of intermediate species of organic acids. Particularly, myristic, stearic acids, etc., appeared to be in a higher amount at an initial temperature of 300 °C, however, their selectivity was markedly reduced to 5.41% with further temperature increase, up to a value of 400 °C. This could be clarified by the temperature effect on accelerating the kinetics of consecutive hydrogenation of triglycerides and the transformation of carboxylic acids through carbonylation/carboxylation reactions [75]. Besides, at the lower temperature of 300 °C, the resulting products generated hydrocarbons at low percentages, suggesting the dominance of cracking reaction rather than deoxygenation reaction. In contrast to this, increasing temperature shifted the product selectivity strongly towards a series of paraffinic hydrocarbons. This indicated that higher temperatures promoted the breakage and decarboxylation/decarbonylation reactions, leading to an alkanes selectivity of 48.45% at 400 °C. In conjunction with the increase in temperature, Co-promoted catalysts dominated in CO bond rupture. In concurrence with other reports in the literature [32,76], supported Co catalysts revealed the highest selectivity towards deoxygenated products. Based on the experimental findings, there was no indication of isoparaffin formation during this course of the reaction. Indeed, the existence of branched chains in the target product is preferred for cleaner and more environmentally friendly combustion and provides a better cold filter plugging point [77]. Moreover, it is worth remarking that with the increase in temperature to 400 °C, the formation of naphthenes (cycloalkanes) and aromatic compounds tended to raise to 6.69% and 18.29%. In contrast, the maximum selectivity (7.99%) of olefins was obtained at 300 °C, however, a further increase in the temperature results in the total elimination of olefins. A comparable observation was made in a distinct study in which HDO was performed at high temperatures caused by a rise in the content of naphthene and aromatic compounds [78]. The mechanism of stepwise aromatic formation could be described as follows: in the first step, alkanes are catalytically converted to olefins through dehydrogenation on metal sites. The resulting olefins from cracking and dehydrogenation reactions are transformed into cycloalkanes by Diels–Alder cyclization on acid sites. Subsequently, while some portions of the cycloalkanes are converted into aromatics and H2 through a dehydrogenation reaction, the remainder of the cycloalkanes part is undergone to hydrogen transfer reaction as it consumes the olefins and produces aromatics and alkanes [79]. It should also be pointed out that the excessive amounts of the Brønsted acid sites, exacerbated the polymerization of olefins, resulting in a more complex formation of coke on Co/γ-Al2O3. It can be inferred from these results that the proper amount of the Brønsted acid sites may be conducive to paraffin cracking, however, the excess amount of it can lead to carbon formation [80]. According to Fig. 11(b), the fraction of bio-jet alkane series showed a progressive increase in the proportion of hydrocarbons, whereas the level of green diesel range hydrocarbons tended to reduce constantly as the reaction temperature increased from 300 to 400 °C. When comparing the percentages for the aviation range of alkanes, with green diesel fuel, a high selectivity, 56.70%, for bio-jet fuel was observed at 400 °C, while the highest selectivity for green diesel was achieved at 350 °C, which was 16.78%. This means that higher temperature was beneficial for cracking reactions which converted long-chain hydrocarbons into short-chain hydrocarbons. This result, in line with previous observation [13] underpins that higher temperature is an important determinant of sort and long-chain paraffinic compounds. 3.2.2 Effect of the reaction time The reaction time has a major role in influencing the catalyst performance on conversion rate and product selectivities for HDO reaction. The effect of the time interval within 4 to 8 h on the catalytic HDO of safflower oil at 350 °C and 25 bar H2 initial pressure was examined over the Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, and corresponding results are presented in Fig. 12 . As shown in Fig. 12(a), the conversion of safflower oil to hydrocarbon fractions through HDO reaction gradually proceeded over the course of reaction time, and the maximal liquid mass yield of 95.31% was attained at a reaction time of 8 h. Based on the results, longer reaction times exhibited slight changes in selectivity of paraffin. The extension of the reaction time indicated a small effect on the HDO reactions, as reported elsewhere [81,82]. Moreover, it was also demonstrated that fractions of aromatic compounds were at a low level of 9.85% at a reaction time of 4 h, however, the aromatic carbon content tended to gradually increase to 35.14% over an extended reaction time of 8 h. Thus, the results suggest that in addition to the initial cracking reactions, triglycerides underwent further cyclic isomerization and aromatization to form aromatic hydrocarbons. On the contrary, the resulting acid intermediates resulted in an almost five-fold decrease with reaction time elevated thus probably making a significant contribution to aromatic groups. The detection of high aromatic compounds might be associated with the presence of strong Lewis acid sites by increasing the dehydrogenation, aromatization, deoxygenation reaction and the high content of unsaturated fatty acids to increase the aromatic formation [83]. The formation of other compounds such as alcohols, ketones, aldehyde, etc. at prolonged reaction temperature might be explained by the results of poor catalytic cracking of triglycerides, mainly due to the coke formation during reaction time. The condensation of reaction intermediates (coke formation) is caused by the following cases i) more active sites on the catalyst surface, leading to undesirable reactions, such as polymerization, ii) high-density composition of the feedstock, and iii) a large number of Lewis acid sites and pore size of catalyst which aggravate polycondensation reactions [83]. The performance of the Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in fuel selectivity was elaborately evaluated over the course of reaction time, and the results are shown in Fig. 12(b). The selectivity of bio-jet fuel reached a maximum of 56.29% and the selectivity of green diesel reached a minimum of 3.54% when the reaction time was 6 h. However, the extension of reaction time to 8 h presented an opposite pattern of results, leading to higher fractions of green diesel of 21.51% and lower fractions of bio-jet fuel of 45.80%. However, the appropriate reaction time for the next stage of research was determined as 8 h, since prolonged reaction time exerted a significant influence on total paraffinic hydrocarbons. 3.2.3 Effect of the initial H2 pressure Another factor of paramount importance that affects the selectivity of a bio-jet fuel is the initial H2 pressure for catalytic HDO of triglycerides. Not only does the utilization of H2 create a conducive atmosphere for minimizing aromatic hydrocarbon production but it also benefits from suppressing coke formation [84]. In the present study, the initial H2 ranged from 25 to 75 bar at 350 °C for 4 h, and the respective results are given in Fig. 13 . The alkane content of the products slightly enhanced from 45.42% to 48.07% with the rise of H2 pressure from 25 to 75 bar, respectively. Raising H2 pressure provides adsorption of H2 on the metal sites, leading to higher H2 activation and HDO activity [85]. Besides, the high H2 pressure is the benefit to improving the substantial level of cracking and enables them to participate in free radical chain reactions [86]. The maximum isoparaffinic hydrocarbon was 3.01% obtained at 50 bar, namely the degree of isomerization reaction increased. However, the isoparaffin content of the product decreased to 1.21% as pressure was increased to 75 bar. The possible reason behind this phenomenon is that increased pressure might contribute to a higher proportion of oxygen-containing substituents, and thus suppressing isomerization [77]. At a low level of H2 pressure (<50 bar), CC bond cleavages occurred in the reaction mixture to a significant extent during HDO of safflower oil, which in turn, gave rise to the reduction of paraffin while increasing unsaturated intermediate chemical compounds. Thus, unsaturated intermediates led to increased aromatization which could be turned into coke precursor deposited on the surface of the catalyst [87]. This is explained by the declined paraffin content which partly contributed to the increased in aromatics content, almost tripling from 5.35% to 15.98% when the pressure went up to 50 bar. More critically, albeit representing a small fraction as seen in Fig. 13(a), the decreasing trend in liquid mass yield fortified the fact of coke formation. A considerable variation in the naphthenes concentrations of the product was obvious as the applied H2 pressure ranged from 25 to 75 bar. Maximum naphthenes formation of 11.97% was achieved at 75 bar, whereas the lowest concentration of naphthenes in the target product was 5.89% at 50 bar. Therefore, a moderate level of pressure was benefit in contributing to the dehydrogenation of naphthenes and in turn boosting the subsequent formations of aromatics. The dehydrogenation step is considered to be a rate-determining step, which is endothermic, thus needing high temperature and low pressure in aromatization [79]. This was proved to be suitably accurate by results available in both Fig. 11 and Fig. 13. The olefins fraction was quite sensitive to initial H2 pressure, which was 5.24% at H2 pressure of 25 bar, then vanished entirely with the increment of initial pressure to 50 bar and finally remarkably went up to 5.51% with further pressure to 75 bar. Contrariwise, a high amount of other oxygenates showed a considerably declined trend from 24.65% to 7.97% within studied range of initial pressure. These findings infer that more volume of hydrogen was adsorbed on the catalyst surface, where active centers provide hydrogenated reactions. Furthermore, the production of acid intermediates showed a pronounced dependency on the initiall H2 pressure and continually increased from 8.06% to 15.39% within applied pressure. As indicated in Fig. 13(a), the initial H2 pressure of 25 bar was insufficient for the conversion of the deoxygenation of safflower triglycerides, leading to a liquid mass yield of 85.21%. A similar observation was reported by Anand et al. [88], where a significant reduction in hydrocracking of triglycerides was obtained due to a low level of H2 pressure caused to mass transfer constraints and less adsorption rate onto active sites of the catalyst. However, an increase in pressure up to 75 bar showed a moderate improvement in the HDO efficiency, reaching a value of 89.51%. As discussed in the previous results in the literature [89], another probable reason exists for this situation, as follows: an increase in H2 pressure is a pivotal factor for the enhancement of hydrogenation saturation and hydrogenolysis and side-chain breaking as well, and thus, presumably, results in much smaller hydrocarbon species. However, according to Fig. 13(b), this seems to be inconsistent with present results since the total amount of green diesel and jet fuel was found to augment in the increasing range of initial pressure. Notably, the selectivities of jet fuel range paraffin increased remarkably from 45.80% to 56.59% as the H2 pressure increased from 25 to 75 bar whereas there was a significant drop of 9% in green diesel amount. This can be explained by the enhancing level of crack severity due to the increment of pressure, congruent with prior reports [62,79]. 3.3 Effect of different metal oxide supports The selection of support material for catalyst preparation is of utmost importance since it can potentially modify structural, textural and active phase-linked properties. In this context, the employment of appropriate catalyst support is a key point for the determination of the activity of the HDO and the selectivity of different chain hydrocarbons. Extensive investigations of the catalytic performance of the Co-supported on different metal oxides were carried out to determine comparatively the catalysis' ability in HDO of safflower oil under the operating conditions: 350 °C of reaction temperature, 8 h of reaction duration and 75 bar of H2 initial pressure, and relevant results are given in Fig. 14 . The results from Fig. 14(a) indicated that Co/ZnO was found to exhibit higher n-alkane selectivity by far in comparison to other catalysts. Among the catalysts studied the content of n-paraffins was as follows: Co/ZnO (59.64%) > Co/ZrO2 (52.41%) > Co/γ-Al2O3 (48.07%) > Co/TiO2 (39.89%). This relation can be explained as follows: suitable acid sites provide active sites to absorb oxygen-containing bio-oil on the surface and activate the CO bonds in those molecules, but strong acidity will give rise to a coke formation and consequently deactivate catalysts [90]. In this connection, the higher acidic nature of both Co/γ-Al2O3 and Co/TiO2 gave an unfavorable increase in coke formation (depicted in Fig. 17) which decreased selectivity for linear alkanes. Another strong point that reinforces this outcome is that supported catalysts of smaller particle sizes can be effective in the HDO of triglycerides for paraffine hydrocarbon production. In other words, the smaller the average size of the particle, the greater the effectiveness of the active sites exposed to a reaction system, thus the higher the activity of the catalyst [91]. In this respect, the findings suggest that the high dispersal of Co into the tetrahedral coordination of ZnO, and the small size of the Co/ZnO, contributed to the spectral increase in the catalyzing activity of Co/ZnO. The comparison of the experimental results showed that not each prepared catalyst could describe the key features of the catalyst in the isomerization activity of the n-alkane. Only Co/γ-Al2O3 and Co/ZnO produced isomerized alkanes, with a small percentage of 1.20 and 1.11, respectively. In the literature, it is stated that the content of isomers is not dependent only on moderately acidic properties of catalysts and useful metal sites but also relative to reaction conditions, particularly temperature [92]. Additionally, Co/ZnO was an active and selective catalyst for HDO upgrading of safflower oil to produce aromatic range hydrocarbons (12.58%). Co, in combination with the acid site of ZnO, was an ideally conducive environment for the oligomerization of the alkenes, followed by cyclization and dehydrogenation, resulting in a higher rate of the formation of aromatics [93]. It is also clear from the inferred conclusion that there is an absence of olefins in the resultant product. Although the high concentrations of aromatic compounds in jet fuel are not favorable, the maximum amount of aromatic compounds in jet fuel has been set at 25.0% in accordance with ASTMD1319 [31]. Noteworthy is also that over the Co/TiO2, almost three-fold more free fatty acids in the resulting product were formed in comparison to the most active catalyst of Co/ZnO. Indeed, this, in turn, provided a clear understanding of its respective lower paraffinity of the hydrocarbon selectivity. Since it is presumed that the selectivity of paraffinic hydrocarbons is enhanced as a result of the successful interaction of intermediate acids and H2 [94]. It should be noted that Co/TiO2 played an important role in the removing of oxygen-containing substances (aldehydes, ketones and phenolics, etc.). Although in the case of Co/ZnO, the oxygen-containing products obtained were quite low in contrast to Co/γ-Al2O3 and Co/ZrO2, Co/TiO2 was able to eliminate all undesirable oxygen-containing intermediates. The spillover effect favors the adsorption of active species on the support and surface diffusion towards active centers of the catalyst [95]. In line with this, TiO2 was found to promote H2 spillover and enhance the dissociation of H2, facilitating catalytic activity towards HDO by transferring dissociated atomic hydrogen adsorption across catalyst surfaces [96,97]. According to experimental data, Fig. 14(b), all products contained primarily a jet fuel fraction followed by a fraction of the green diesel range, and no formation of the gasoline, which suggests that all reactions were mainly triggered by the simultaneous deoxygenation and cracking reactions. Co/ZnO catalyst produced a large percentage of fractions of the jet fuel of 65.96%, with only 5.62% of the green diesel production, whereas Co/ZrO2 showed lower performance in correlation concerning bio-aviation fuel production with a value of 45.90% but exhibited a significant improvement of diesel selectivity of 26.71%. These results further confirmed that the enhancement of Co/ZnO activity was based upon the presence of a sufficient proportion of weak and medium acid sites. Based on the statements made by previous researchers, the catalytic activity of a catalyst relies, in large part, on the structural and surface characteristics of catalyst material along with its chemical content, which affects the active location of the catalyst, the reachability of molecules to pore sizes of catalysts and the mass transfer of reactant and products [98]. However, it was the most interesting finding of the present study that the highly active and excellent selectivity for bio-jet fuel did not have a significant relationship with the structural characteristics of the catalyst, rather the performance of the catalyst of Co/ZnO was based on the acidity of the catalyst. 3.4 Reusability of Co/ZnO catalyst The reusability of catalysts plays a crucial role in industrial applications in terms of the economy and sustainability of production capacity. Reusability tests were conducted using a highly active Co/ZnO catalyst, and during the catalyst reusability experiments, the operating variables were set to their optimized values, temperature of 350 °C and an initial H2 pressure of 75 bar for 8 h, for each run. Once a run was completed, the catalyst was filtered and washed with methanol, and then dried in an oven before being used again in the next run. Fig. 15 presents the distribution of liquid products based on all types of hydrocarbons (aromatics, alkenes, paraffins, and isoparaffins) and oxygenated intermediates. In Fig. 15, the hydrocarbon distribution is 84.8% and 83.6% in the first and second cycles, respectively, whereas it decreases to 77.3% in the third cycle. The decline in catalyst performance can be attributed to the significant reduction in active sites caused by irreversible surface adsorption of intermediates and/or reactants, as well as pore blockage resulting from carbon deposits [28]. However, upon examining the results, it was determined that the loss in hydrocarbon selectivity after the second cycle was less than 10%. This indicates that future modifications to the catalyst to further enhance its stability can help maintain its high activity and selectivity. 3.5 FTIR analysis of product The catalytic performance of catalysts prepared by using various support materials was examined under the most suitable reaction conditions for the Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst as stated above, and the compounds were identified by GC–MS. For further confirmation of the obtained product composition, FTIR analysis was also performed to determine functional groups of safflower oil and corresponding products from supported Co catalysts with various supports, and the results are illustrated in Fig. 16 . As shown in FTIR spectra (Fig. 16), the observed peaks between 2800 and 3000 cm−1 indicates stretching vibrations pertaining to CH stretching vibrations of alkanes and alkenes, which are derived from the esters chain of safflower oil [99]. The distinctive peak at the wavenumber of 1742 cm−1 is attributed to the C=O stretching of carboxylic acids in safflower oil, and it was found to shift towards the short-wavenumber region of ∼1710 cm−1 in the presence of different catalysts. The reduced intensity of the peak in those spectra proved that the catalytic HDO reaction allowed a high efficiency of triglycerides conversion. However, more significantly, the FTIR spectra of the product from the catalytic HDO of Co/ZnO revealed almost the complete disappearance of the carboxyl C=O stretch band at 1716 cm−1. Therefore, the results obtained with GC–MS (Supplementary file, Table S1) showed to be in perfect correlation with those obtained with the FTIR technique. Additionally, the presence of stretching vibration at 1460 cm−1 is linked with the presence of hydrocarbons, whereas the small peaks appearing between 900 and 650 cm−1 are related to the aromatic ring absorption band [9]. 3.6 TG of used catalyst TG measurement of spent catalysts was also conducted to examine the extent of coke deposition on the catalyst surface during HDO of safflower oil, and the comparative results are given in Fig. 17 . According to the TG profiles of used catalysts, the weight drop during the heating up to 200 °C was a result of the moisture and residual organic molecular absorbed on catalyst surfaces [100]. Aside from them, it was noticeable that each Co-based catalyst showed a different tendency for coke resistance. The mass loss up to 700 °C could be related to the burning of the accumulated char/coke and hydrocarbon residues on the catalyst surface [101]. From this viewpoint, the amount of coke deposited on the spent catalysts decreased in the following order Co/TiO2 > Co/γ-Al2O3 > Co/ZrO2 > Co/ZnO. The catalyst prepared using ZnO showed the highest increase in activity and selectivity toward jet fuel range paraffin in HDO of safflower oil as compared to other catalysts and these results manifested in excellent agreement with TGA results of spent catalysts. 3.7 Reaction mechanism Proposing the specific reaction mechanism for HDO processes is generally challenging task as it is influenced by multiple parameters, including catalyst type, temperature, hydrogen pressure, LHSV, the H2/oil ratio and so on. However, suggesting proper mechanism for reaction becomes imperative to explain the formation of different products during the process. With this aim in view, the authors have proposed a potential reaction mechanism for the HDO of the biofuel precursor using Co/ZnO catalyst based on the above results and discussions, and the corresponding results illustrated in Fig. 18 . The first step of the HDO process involves saturating the double bonds in triglycerides. An excessive amount of hydrogen incorporate into the process to break the double bonds and cracking process subsequently converts triglycerides into fatty acids, as shown in Fig. 18. Hydrocarbons (n-alkanes and alkenes) and oxygen-containing alcohols or aldehydes are produced from fatty acids through deoxygenation reactions, which initially involve hydrodeoxygenation, decarbonylation, and decarboxylation, followed by hydropyrolysis. As evident from the XPS and XRD results, Co exits in different crystal structures within the Co/ZnO catalyst. These different crystal structures may have affected the HDO reactions in different ways. In particular, metallic cobalt is known to be effective in hydrogenation of C = O bonds, whereas the promotion of decarboxylation and decarbonylation by the existence of Co-oxide species [102]. The next step of the process involves the use of a Co/ZnO catalyst which facilitated hydrogenation of alkenes, hydrodeoxygenation of oxygenated compounds using catalytically active metalic sides, and hydrocracking of long-chain n-alkanes over acidic functional groups on the surface of ZnO [103]. In line with the results from Co/ZnO catalyst, eliminating nearly all oxygenenated compunds may have enhanced the prevalence of paraffinic compounds. It was reported that, the moderate acidity of Co based catalyst was found to play a role in promoting reactions that resulted in the saturation, leading to an increase in the conversion of intermediate compounds containing oxygen [104]. Additionally, isomerization, cyclization and cracking reactions begin to occur as side reactions. On the other hand, in the light of findings, Co/ZnO catalyst did not yield satisfactory results with respect to the production of isoparaffin compounds. This can be attributed to various reaction parameters, such as H2 partial pressure and temperature, as well as the choice of catalyst support material and active component. Since geometric and electronic factors of catalysts are believed to be the primary contributors to the strong isomerization activity. In addition, it is also possible that an adequate level of Brønsted acidity could be another factor leading to the observed effects [105]. 3.8 Comparison of catalytic activities The catalytic activity of Co/ZnO was evaluated in comparison to those of previously reported catalysts for oil upgrading through the HDO process, and the corresponding results are listed in Table 6 . According to Table 6, it appears that some of the research studies have shown a higher catalytic activity compared with the present research. Especially, noble metal-based heterogeneous catalysts such as Pd exhibit high activity towards catalytic HDO of long-chain fatty acids to produce high-grade aviation biofuels. However, the high cost and limited availability of novel-based catalysts are the biggest obstacles to their industrial application. Therefore, the development of catalysts based on non-noble nature with high efficiency, and low cost, is of significant importance in the application of SAF technologies in practice. On the other hand, outperforming the other catalysts considered, one of the main obvious problems associated with them is their complexity in the preparation, which frequently entails multiple preparation steps and many purification stages along with a reduction step. By combining these data, the main advantages in this study include the use of inexpensive catalysts and their simple preparation, the mild reactions, the high yield and the ability to re-use catalysts. Thus, the present study sheds light on the development and use of heterogeneous catalysts based on transition metals with high sensitivity and stability, for the replacement of catalysts based on the precious metal in the research field of HDO. 4 Conclusions The increase in the economic feasibility of the HDO process depends on the development of a novel non-precious catalyst as well as moderate reaction conditions for high selectiveness toward biomass-derived jet fuel. Therefore, this research aimed to synthesize a high-active and s catalyst for future biorefinery applications. Under the experimental circumstances used in the present work, the temperature had the most influence on the HDO of safflower oil, compared to the other two variables. The reaction at the moderate temperature of 350 °C was considered optimal in the presence of Co/γ-Al2O3, even though it resulted in higher selectivity of bio-jet fuel at the temperature above. Because higher temperatures promoted polymerization and condensation reactions which resulted in the higher formation of coke. High H2 pressure, however, enabled the hydrogenation, decarbonization and carbonylation reactions over Co/γ-Al2O3, to produce fuels for the jet range. Under the appropriate experimental conditions (350 °C, 8 h and 75 bar H2), the maximum bio-jet fuel and diesel selectivities for Co/γ-Al2O3 were 56.59% and 12.39%, respectively. In contrast, the Co-promoted ZnO catalyst resulted in a satisfactory selectivity for the formation of bio-jet range fuel selectivity (65.96%) whereas that of diesel (5.62%) displayed the reverse trend. This was the primary reason that the moderate surface acidity of Co/ZnO played a decisive role in the upgrading of safflower oil to bio-jet fuel through HDO. The present results will serve as a reference for future studies, and additional research that will be conducted in the continuation of this study is listed in the following order: • Iso-alkanes comprise one of the more important classes of hydrocarbons in aviation fuel. However, none of the catalysts gave a resultant product with sufficient content of isoalkanes, therefore, some potential modifications to Co/ZnO catalyst might be implemented to meet standards for bio-jet fuel. • Changing catalyst preparation procedures might be evaluated in the catalytic response in the HDO of safflower oil. • An efficient fractional distillation might be performed to separate the bio-jet fuel from the resultant, and the obtained products would be further analyzed in terms of their physicochemical properties to be compared to Jet A-1. • A follow-up study regarding a blending process of fossil-kerosene and obtained bio-jet fuel could be implemented to identify the critical properties of blends as a supply of aviation fuel. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic hydrodeoxygenation process provides an alternative route for the production of renewable jet fuel, which can directly replace petroleum-derived hydrocarbons. To this end, the catalytic performance of Co-based catalysts supported by different metal oxides, γ-Al2O3, TiO2, ZnO and ZrO2 was tested to evaluate their catalytic activity and product selectivity in hydrodeoxygenation of safflower oil. The results indicated that catalytic performance changed in response to acidity, morphologies and particle size of catalysts. Benefiting from these combined characteristics, Co/ZnO catalyst exhibited a highly catalytic activity, being capable of producing jet fuel-range hydrocarbon selectivity of 65.96% under reaction parameters of 350 °C of reaction temperature, 8 h of reaction time and 75 bar of H2 initial pressure. In addition to superior activity, the coke content of Co/ZnO was much lower compared to other employed catalysts thereby affecting the stability of the catalyst and resulting in less deactivation and coke formation.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrodeoxygenation of safflower oil over cobalt-doped metal oxide catalysts for bio-aviation fuel production
